questions.question: What is inflation?
options: A decrease in the overall price level of goods and services.
A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services.
An increase in the value of a currency.
A decrease in the money supply.
questions.answer: B. A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common cause of inflation?
What is hyperinflation?
options: A moderate increase in prices over an extended period.
A very high and typically accelerating inflation.
questions.answer: B. A very high and typically accelerating inflation.

questions.question: Which index is commonly used to measure inflation in the United States?
How does inflation impact savers?
options: Increases the purchasing power of savings.
Decreases the real value of savings.
Leads to higher interest rates for savers.
questions.answer: B. Decreases the real value of savings.

questions.question: Which country experienced hyperinflation in the early 20th century, with prices doubling every few days?
What is the Phillips Curve used to illustrate?
options: The relationship between inflation and unemployment.
The relationship between interest rates and inflation.
The impact of government spending on inflation.
The correlation between GDP and inflation.
questions.answer: A. The relationship between inflation and unemployment.

questions.question: What is demand-pull inflation?
options: Inflation caused by a decrease in aggregate demand.
Inflation caused by an increase in aggregate supply.
Inflation caused by an increase in aggregate demand.
Inflation caused by a decrease in aggregate supply.
questions.answer: C. Inflation caused by an increase in aggregate demand.

questions.question: Which central bank is responsible for monetary policy in the Eurozone?
What is the impact of deflation on the economy?
options: Increases the real value of debt.
Can lead to a downward economic spiral.
questions.answer: D. Can lead to a downward economic spiral.
